subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: So said  Mike Colbert   on  2002-12-13 ... A TestCase object is a test fixture. This is definitely an article that either Dave or I need
messageBody:
So said Mike Colbert <mbcolbert@...> on 2002-12-13
--------------------

>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Colbert <mbcolbert@y...>"
><mbcolbert@y...> wrote:
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Astels <dave@s...>" <dave@s...>
>> wrote:
>> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Eric Armstrong
><eric.armstrong@s...>
>> wrote:
>> > > "Mike Colbert " wrote:
>> > >
>> > > > One technique we use, with Java, is to implement our JUnit
>> > > > TestCases as static inner classes.
>> > [...]
>> > > This sounds like a really great idea.
>> >
>> > Sorry, but it's not.
>> >
>> > <aside>
>> > Hmm.. how very Canadian of me. I'm not really sorry at all. It
>> works
>> > much better when you don't have TestCases tied tightly to classes
>> > being tested.
>> > </aside>
>> >
>>
>>
>> What works much better? How do you do Test-Driven Design without
>> tightly tying your TestCases to the classes being tested?
>>
>
>My reply was a bit hasty and poorly formed ... Let me rephrase my
>question. Why is it better, easier, more practical, pragmatic,
>and/or more productive to not associate TestCases with classes in a
>TDD environment? Or should I wait for the newsletter?

A TestCase object is a test fixture. This is definitely an article that
either Dave or I need to write.

Dave?
